Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dimensions: The Macroalgal Microbiome in Space and Time---Maintaining Primary Producers in the Atlantic Rocky Intertidal Zone
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intertidal macro algae ('seaweeds') provide habitat, shelter and food to many invertebrates and young fishes. Much is known about how intertidal algae react to natural stresses, but little is known about the natural community of bacteria associated with these algae. Past studies in the laboratory found that some 'seaweeds' disintegrate after removal of their bacteria with antibiotics suggesting these bacteria are essential to the health of their hosts. This research will examine the genetic, taxonomic, and functional aspects of biodiversity of bacteria associated with several 'seaweeds' that are particularly important to the general health of marine ecosystems. The research will determine how these bacteria change with season, position within the intertidal zone and latitudinal range. Stability or change in the bacterial species associated with a host will be examined by studying the particular bacterial genes that are present at different sampling times and by studying host responses to inoculations with particular bacteria. The work will also study whether any bacteria are inhibited by the environmental extremes found across the intertidal zone or over latitude, especially at the southern borders of a host's range where climate change may disturb the bacterial community on the host. Researchers will deposit isolates and voucher specimens into public collections, and, in collaboration with trained citizen scientists, will provide digital access to all algal materials within the University of Maine Herbarium. The multi-faceted data collected during this research will aid studies by other intertidal ecologists.

How macroalgal microbiomes change in space and time is poorly known. Is there a 'cool, wet' versus a 'hot, dry' macroalgal microbiome(s)? If so, how does this affect host function? Here, microbiomes will be characterized over the vertical gradient of the intertidal zone on the Maine shore in differentially zoned species within each of two prominent genera, Fucus (rockweed) and Porphyra (laver). Contemporaneously, a trans-Atlantic study of microbiomes of the mid-zone Porphyra umbilicalis and Fucus vesiculosus will determine whether compositional changes found over an intertidal stress gradient are mirrored over the latitudinal range of mid-zoned species. If so, does this matter? This question will be answered by using shotgun metagenomic analyses to compare the genetic composition with the characterized taxonomic composition of the macroalgal microbiomes. Environmental variation associated with microbiome collections will be measured with in situ sensors and from archival and real time data available from government climate services (e.g., NOAA). The potential to detect changes over historic time will be assessed using herbarium specimens. To study bacteria that are likely to be most critical to normal structure and function of Fucus and Porphyra, the researchers will focus on bacterial isolations from spores and fertilized eggs, aided by flow cytometry and single cell genomics. To establish the criticality of these associations, microbiome-depleted embryos will be inoculated with such bacterial isolates, and the resulting interaction will be investigated by analysis of the host transcriptome with RNA-Seq. The temperature tolerance of key bacterial species (operational taxonomic units) will be established in laboratory experiments. This research will serve as an important trans-Atlantic baseline of the biodiversity of macroalgal microbiomes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: We investigated how environmental stress affects the diversity and distribution of intertidal bacterial communities associated with three species of habitat-forming brown algae (Fucus spiralis, high zone; Fucus vesiculosus, mid zone; Fucus distichus, low zone) and two species of red algae (Porphyra linearis, high zone; Porphyra umbilicalis, high zone and mid zone) that are foods for intertidal animals. We combined studies of bacterial communities on natural (unmanipulated) Fucus adults, while conducting an experimental transplant. Our objective was to determine whether the bacterial community of mid zone adults (F. vesiculosus zone) would change when they were transplanted to the high zone (F. spiralis zone) in either of two treatments. One treatment (“Dry”) did not manipulate the adults after the transplant; thus, they were exposed to the higher levels of environmental stress in the high zone. In the other high zone treatment (“Wet”), transplanted adults were watered with seawater at regular intervals during the daytime low tide when the mid zone F. vesiculosus were still underwater, because we hypothesized that desiccation was the major stress of the high zone.  At the experiment’s end, bacterial communities of the natural congeners were significantly different from each other. In the experiment, DRY holdfast bacterial communities were not significantly different from the natural high zone community on F. spiralis holdfasts. WET holdfast communities were significantly different from F. spiralis communities but not from procedural F. vesiculosus back-transplants in the mid zone. Over 6000 different ecotypes in many genera were identified by differences in DNA sequences. This work suggests that principles of community ecology gained from studies of larger organisms apply to bacterial communities.  Analysis of traits of individual bacterial isolates continues, including genomic analyses. Finally, our research at larger scales (the North Atlantic) of host bacterial communities collected in this project should be published in 2021.  

 Broad Impacts:  We digitally curated most of the existing algal specimens (about 9,000 specimens) in the University of Maine’s herbarium (MAINE) and added about 500 new herbarium sheets of Fucus and Porphyra from our study sites in North America and Europe.  A new, comprehensive digital database is accompanied by digital photographs of each herbarium specimen, and many of these are already available in macroalgae.org (The Macroalgal Herbarium Portal), while all will be deposited there by the end of 2021. These collections are important to analysis of continuing climate change. Sequence data from our studies of macroalgal host-associated bacteria will continue to be submitted to the NCBI Sequence Read Archive. The scope of our research led to collaborations among American, Canadian, and European senior scientists, postdoctoral fellows, graduate students, and undergraduates, about half of whom were women. University of Maine graduate degrees (1 Ph.D., 1 M.S.), undergraduate Honors Thesis degrees (2 B.S. degrees with Highest Honors), and degrees with capstone senior theses (3 undergraduate B. S. degrees) were awarded based on research accomplished in meeting the objectives of this research project, and 8 other undergraduates participated in field and lab work. With financial support from their European institutions, 4 postdocs, 1 graduate student, and 4 undergraduates participated in field work for the project in Scotland, Norway, Portugal, and Spain. The research provided strong training in laboratory and field techniques and how to work collaboratively in a large team to achieve project goals.
